questions.infoText: They are organisms that have five arms and reddish coloration. They are carnivorous and feed mainly on mollusks. The digestion of food takes place outside their body, that is, they throw their stomachs and digestive juice out of the body and afterwards swallow the already digested food.
questions.name: Starfish

questions.infoText: They are echinoderms, related to the Starfish. They feed on delicate algae, scraping and tearing them off the rocks, leaving only the coralline crustose, which are of a pink color and resistant to herbivory. They can be sheltered in holes called "pits". Their color is black and they have sharp spines, which can pierce human skin and cause infections. Many people think they are able to "throw" their spines, but that is not true.
questions.name: Black sea urchin

questions.infoText: Crustaceans present on the Brazilian coast and highly prized in cooking, being a luxury food. Therefore, they are threatened and there is the season of the “closure”, in which no one can hunt these organisms. They can live in depths of up to 90 meters and usually hide in cracks in the rocks during the day and go out at night to feed. Females can lay up to 100,000 eggs, which are trapped in the bottom of their abdomens. They have 5 pairs of legs in the thorax, belonging to the Decapoda order.
questions.name: Red lobster

questions.infoText: They are organisms that look like algae, but are actually animals related to Starfish, which belong to the class Crinoidea. They have 5 branched arms, which resemble feathers, and which are used in their feeding by filtration, as they serve as barriers for particles suspended in water.
questions.name: Sea lily

questions.infoText: Animals of the group of cnidarians, with cylinder-shaped body containing one end attached to the substrate and the other surrounded by tentacles, among which is the mouth. They catch the food with the tentacles. They are animals that only occur in Brazil and produce a molecule called caissarone, which may contribute to the production of drugs for intestinal disorders.
questions.name: Sea anemone

questions.infoText: Individuals of the species Mussismilia hispida are endemic to Brazil, that is, occur only on the coast of this country and nowhere else in the world. They live in clear, shallow and warm water environments (above 20°C). They are cnidarians that form colonies that look like brains, with coloration that can range from gray, blue, and green.
questions.name: Brain Coral

questions.infoText: They are colonial cnidarians of orange coloration. The color is given by the algae that are associated with their tissues, in an ecological relation that we call symbiosis. If the temperature of the water increases greatly, these algae may die and cause the whitening and subsequent death of these colonies. They live between 2 and 7 meters deep and the colonies are covered by a mucus produced by them, which is used by fishermen as an analgesic. This mucus gave these organisms the popular name in Brazil of "baba-de-boi" (something like or slime).

Little known to most of the population, these organisms form one of the largest deposits of calcium carbonate in the world and are threatened by the acidification of sea water that is occurring as a consequence of global climate change. The acidity of water prevents the formation of limestone structures by marine organisms. These organisms are red algae that form large submarine banks, as if they were pinkish rocks on the seabed and their name in Greek means "pink or red rock." In Brazil, they occur mainly in the Abrolhos National Marine Park, occupying an area of approximately 20,000 km2.
questions.name: Rhodolith

questions.infoText: They are brown algae, abundant in the Brazilian coast, mainly in the Southeast region. They occupy the area of the rocky shores that is at the limit of the low tide, being partially exposed to the air during some hours of the day. These algae have the body divid e d into a central axis and lateral branches called blades, which look like leaves, but are not. Still, they may have air vesicles  or floating vesicles) that cause individuals to float in water. Elsewhere in the world, some species of these algae may form extensive floating banks, which serve as a shelter and source of food for various species, such as sea turtles.
questions.name: Sargasso

questions.infoText: Marine vertebrate that can live for up to 67 years and adults weigh 200kg on average. They have a strong jaw, a large head and a rigid carapace, characterized by the presence of 5 pairs of dorsal plates. They can be submerged for up to 4 hours without interruption, but generally the dives are between 15 and 30 minutes. They feed main lyon invertebrates such as crustaceans and mollusks. Females begin the reproductive phase between the ages of 17 and 33 years. The eggs are placed in holes dug in the sand of the beach where the female was born, which are covered with sand. Many puppies die soon after birth and this, coupled with the delay to sexual maturity, causes these organisms to be threatened.
questions.name: Loggerhead Sea Turtle

questions.infoText: Green algae of the genus Ulva. They are related to terrestrial plants. They have chloroplasts with chlorophyll a and b, which are pigments related to the photosynthesis process. The morphology of these algae is foliaceous and they are highly appreciated by some fish and turtles. They usually occur in shallow water, in places with high amounts of organic matter or with pollution by sewage.
questions.name: Sea Lettuce

questions.infoText: Sessile and crustose organisms, colored between orange and red. They are filtering organisms, and sea water enters the various pores of the body and runs through the system of channels with cells that absorb nutrients from the water. These pores characterize the phylum of these organisms (Porifera). The skeleton is formed by spicules and collagen fibers. They produce a stinging substance that can cause dermatitis.
questions.name: Orange sea sponge

questions.infoText: Although they seem algae, they are actually related to Sea anemones, belonging to the group of cnidarians. They are colonial and the calcareous skeleton supports the individuals of the colony, forming an erect and branched structure, of red coloration. They are bioindicators of climate change because they are sensitive to changes in water temperature.
questions.name: Gorgonia

questions.infoText: They are cephalopod molluscs. They have eight arms with suction cups, arranged around the mouth. They are predators, feeding mainly on fish and crustaceans. They have good vision, which is an advantage when looking for food. They have glands that release paint in times of stress or predators’ scaping. They are much appreciated as food.
questions.name: Octopus

questions.infoText: Algae that form turfs of soft consistency. The thallus is formed of filaments that look like strands of hair, full of branches and red in color. They are appreciated by herbivorous organisms such as fish and hedgehogs. It has a short life cycle and grows very fast.
questions.name: Filamentous red algae

questions.infoText: Colonies of very rigid consistency, orange in color, looking like small trees. The individuals that form the colony are very small, only being possible to visualize them with a magnifying glass or a microscope. Although quite similar to corals, these organisms belong to another group, called Ectoprocta. The species is not native to Brazil, having been brought from Japan.

Also known as “jamanta”, it is a species of fish, from a group related to sharks. It has a diamond-shaped body and a long tail, without a thorn. They can weigh up to 1350 kg. They feed on plankton and small fish.
questions.name: Giant manta ray

questions.infoText: Brown seaweed that has a thallus shaped like a fan. The thallus grows by the margin, which is curled.

Black colored organisms, which have one end of the body fixed to the rocks and the other end formed by two siphons, one where the water and the food enters (inhaling siphon) and the other through which water and excreta comes out (exhaling siphon). The body is covered by a layer of cells called a tunica (from which comes the name of the group to which they belong - Tunicata). They are filterers and gaseous exchanges occur through gills in the pharynx. Although they have a rather complex morphology, they are close relatives of vertebrates, because they have notochord.
questions.name: Black ascidian

questions.infoText: Common fish in the tropical and subtropical seas of the world, abundant in the Brazilian coast. Their body is between 8 and 15 centimeters in length, oval in form and with 5 vertical black stripes in the dorsal part, resembling a insignia of a sergeant. It has a gray color with agglomerated yellowish or blueish portions. It feeds on invertebrates and algae.
questions.name: Sergeant major fish
